title: Design of Experiments

The small numerical example in my Chapter 3 with I = 8 patients is mathematically identical to the example in Chapter 2 of Fisher’s Design of Experiments, although the surrounding narrative is quite dif­fer­ent. For a concise survey of Fisher’s contributions to statistics
Fisher

Fisher in­ven­ted randomization as a statistical method so that a feature of the design of the experiment justified, by a mathematical argument, a par­tic­u­lar statistical inference. As an informal tool for equitable, blinded treatment assignment, randomization existed before Fisher; see Ian Hacking, “Origins of randomization in experimental design
